newsitem.title: UK: SmithKline sees stg cutting FY pft by 8 pct.
newsitem.headline: SmithKline sees stg cutting FY pft by 8 pct.

text.p: SmithKline Beecham Plc finance director Hugh Collum said on Tuesday the strong pound was likely to reduce the group's full-year profits by around eight percent.

Collum told a telephone conference with reporters that the pound had risen by around seven percent since the second quarter of 1996 and by 20 percent against European currencies, cutting reported pre-tax profits by 42 million stg.
"Our best estimate is that the impact on profits will be about eight per cent for the whole of 1997," Collum said.
Collum said 50 percent of the reduction in profit caused by sterling's strength in the quarter was accounted for by comparisons with European currencies, with 20 percent from the U.S.
SmithKline also said it had no plans to follow the lead of Eli Lilly & Co of the U.S. in writing down the value of its pharmacy benefit manager Diversified Pharmaceutical Services (DPS).

Chief executive Jan Leschley defended the decision to buy DPS, which cost SmithKline $2.3 billion in 1994, saying DPS and the troubled Clinical Laboratories operation "give us a competitive advantage that others don't have."
Leschley told Reuters he would still purchase DPS if making the decision today.
